page.title: 04Ecology
page.content: The wooded slopes provide shelter from the strong winds and driving rain for a rich variety of wild life, while springs and streams ensure a plentiful supply of water. Birds seen include:- buzzard, sparrow hawk, kestrel, raven, woodpecker, warbler, owl, tit, heron, crow. Mammals include deer, badger, fox, hare, rabbit, rat, mice and shrew. There are also lizards, newts, and snakes including adders. The whole area is criss crossed by footpaths, including an ancient ridgeway still in use since Roman times. Stowe church- yard and surrounding fields are noted for the numbers of massive ancient yew trees. Felled hillsides are colonised by rhododendron, broom, foxglove, and dense carpets of bluebells. Twenty species of flower were found on Caer Caradoc. Less common flora include spindle, centuary, and purple orchid.
